Also if you haven't seen a Chrsitmas Story then you need to. I highly recommend a Christmas story to anybody. Watch out they do say a lot of bad words in the movie.
This used to be my favorite Christmas movie but over the years it's just really lost its appeal. The old man has always been the best part. Especially when he's off camera fighting the furnace.

I watch this movie every year at Christmas time with my dad and it is our favorite family tradition for the holidays. It's so funny because it's all so true! My dad says it was like that growing up in the fifties and I believe him, but being a kid today is the same as it always has been in some ways. The kid playing Ralphie is fantastic, so perfect. A nice kid you really pull for and you can identify with all his problems. Picked on by a bully, getting a horrible piece of clothing (don't want to spoil it!) for a present and having to wear it when the aunt who gave it to him comes over to visit, it's all so true. The really annoying and spoiled baby sibling. Wanting so desperately to get something for Christmas and then the disappointment of not getting it (or does he?) 10 out of 10 for this hilarious, touching and wonderful film! I'm sad to see the director has passed on.

Review title: How the heck can you shoot your eye out?
Review_body: Funny as heck. Although I missed out on the 50's (and 60's and 70's for that matter), it preaches truths that cross generations. I mean, sticking your tongue to frozen metal is still hip and stupid no matter what decade, and although it's video games and DVD's instead of BB guns, the same principle applies - Mom is just too uncool to let you have it! Simply a joy to watch.

Review title: Am I the only person that hates this movie?
Review_body: Honestly, I can't stand this movie.  I refuse to watch it.  And, as far as I know, I am the ONLY person in the entire world that hates it.  In my opinion, it's horrible. The acting is bad, the plot is bad.. every thing is bad.  Plus, the image of Santa they portray is traumatizing to little kids.  But, I'll stop ranting.  I just want to say that I hate this movie.  And I think I'm the only person that does.
Probably the best Christmas movie ever. It is watched in my house at least a dozen times during the season. Side note my wife got me the Red Ryder bb gun. I have not shot my eye out...yet.

The film itself holds a wholesome feel to the story of an American dream. The American dream. Most of the film centers around Ralphie, a boy obsessed with the idea of receiving a Red Ryder BB Gun as a Christmas gift. The story entails his visions of what exactly the gun would do for him. The defense of his family as a prime example. It contributes the strong belief children have in Santa Claus and the affect that has on them. Christmas brings the kids excitement and hope, in a rustic, 1940s, mid-western town that depicts these hopes through an American dream. The parents, the hard-working father, the home-making mother, together trying to make their boys Christmas wishes true. With humor and style, it finesses the mind into a tale of unparalleled American normalcy and desire. It takes over a perfectly painted idea of Christmas and America and sends the viewer into a whirlwind of jokes, ideas, folklore, and tales that build into the great overall tale that is told throughout the film.

I just finished watching Diary of a Wimpy kid..and I realized how much I love A Christmas Story. I saw this movie for the first time just 3 months back. I was laughing the whole time.I still laugh remembering some scenes from this. 'Flint?Flint who?' and how he looks around when the teacher says 'I know one among you has done this' was simply awesome. 'Soap Poisoining'- I replayed many scenes from this move so many times. Kids looked innocent enough for their age..and nothing looked artificial or crooked..Ralphie simply rrrocked. I was watching Diary of a Wimpy kid with a blank face. I think this movie set a high benchmark :) I highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants to see a movie with good spirit and hearty laughs. I will always remember this movie with a biig smile. Kudos to all who were part of this movie.

I watch this every year and I always enjoy it. This movie was not meant to be totally realistic. The characters and the incidents in the movie are often exaggerated. However that is the way it is supposed to be. It does have some great nostalgic moments. The only scene I disliked was a messy eating scene. I fast forward through that.I thought the cast was very good especially the parents and the boy who had the lead role. There were many 9 year olds in the 1940's who still believed in Santa or who were starting to doubt but not ready to give it up yet. The character of Ralphie was the oldest child so had no older siblings who might spoil the belief for him. There was no TV then. Kids were allowed and encouraged to remain kids for longer. This was just after the great depression so perhaps parents wanted to prolong the happy, innocent child hood. This movie is not meant to be taken seriously. It is meant to be fun and it is fun. I recommend this along with other movies based on Jean Shepherd books to anyone who wants to just watch a fun Christmas movie.

Review title: A Christmas movie I thought I'd imagined.
Review_body:
I must have seen this movie in the late 80s as a kid (born in 82). I had vivid memories of Santa kicking ralphitralphiehe slide and the other kid getting his tongue stuck to the pole. And that was it.
It wasn't until a few days ago, fast forward to December 2020 and I saw an Instagram post about this movie and realised this was the movie that was stuck in the back of my head for over 30 years.I rented a digital copy and sat down and watched it that night.This movie stirs up so much nostalgia, even for me born decades after this movie was set. Though I think growing up in the early 80s is closer to the 40s or 50s than today possibly is lile for children.
My family had 1 tv, a stay at home mum, were fairly poor, walked to school, I had a younger brother and i definitely dreamed of getting one specific toy each Christmas. The super soaker 50 springs to mind one particular year.I think the Christmas message does come through in this film and its clear to me why this movie holds such a strong place to so many people especially the generationgenerations before mine. But I hope newer generations find something in this simple little story about growing up in hard times and figuring out the world and the people you look up to who you think have the world figured out. But even they really don't.I will add this to my list of end of year movies forever now and I'm so happy I rediscovered it after all these years.It's not a classic Christmas story like a christmas carol or its a wonderful life which are magical in their own rights. But a christmas movie paints a picture of a real Christmas lead up so many of us lived. Remembering back to being that age and having that expectation and wonderment for Christmas day. In its own way this movie is very touching and a nice coming of age story for ralphie.I'm so happy to hear that a channel in America plays this for 24 hours straight.

Review title: This is the worst film I've ever seen
Review_body: Im 13 and in my ENTIRE life, I've never seen a movie worse than this!!!!!!! THis was a TERRIBLE movie that practically has no meaning and is terrible. Every year my family makes me watch this and every year i hate it more. This movie just gets stupider as i get older and I will never make my children watch this. Unless they deserved it....like if they murdered someone Thats how bad it is. My advice: NEVER EVER WATCH THIS if you have any common sense you will never lay your eyes on this terrible film. everyone says its a classic. Its not. Die before you watch this.If you think your one of those people who'd like it, be my guest and watch it. Be warned. ITs bad. But u watch it, you're just plain stupid. If you want a better movie, watch Rudolph. Its 10000000000000000000 stars better and I don't even really like that. GOod Luck, but listen to me.

Review title: 9 year old Ralphie must convince his mom, teacher, and even Santa that a BB gun is the perfect Christmas Gift.
Review_body: This is easily in my opinion the best Christmas movie ever made, along with Frank Capra's 1946 classic "It's a Wonderful Life." "A Christmas Story," embodies the true spirit of every child nearing Christmas time. The film is seen through the eyes of a 9 year old boy named Ralphie Parker. Just like most children nearing the holiday season, Ralphie shares a common obsession for a gift. But the only roadblock he faces is the fact that he wants a BB gun. This film is packed with memorable and heartwarming scenes. One unique aspect of "A Christmas Story," is that almost each and every character has their own special moment in the movie. One of the many reasons this movie is so loved and sought after is because Ralphie is such a relatable character. I admit that even I have shared a common need for "Thee," Christmas gift and I'm sure that you, yes you reading this, have had that same feeling. Weather its the old man winning his "Major Award," or even smart assed Schwartz sticking his tongue to the flagpole, "A Christmas Story," is sure to keep you laughing and is able to find a special place in everybody's heart as one of their favorite movies of all time.

As far as I am concerned, this is the best Christmas movie ever.The character of Ralphie is just priceless and the narration is wonderful. I can still remember specific lines from the movie that can make me laugh. Great for the entire family.

Review title: A great FILM, not just a great Christmas film
Review_body: A great FILM, not just a great Christmas film: I've seen it many times. I'll see it many times more.  I saw it in the theater when it came out, and I've never heard an audience laugh so much.During the 24-hour TNT marathon last year, I put it on.  I meant to go do the grocery shopping, but "what do the piggies do ?" was in the next scene...In about 5 minutes the entire family had gathered around.  We ended up watching it twice through.  We swore we'd stop when we got to the part we started, but this flick is worse than crack cocaine: you can't stop with one.It perfectly captures the fear, joy, hope, sadism, and cynicism that is childhood.

Ralphie is a young boy growing up in the 1940's. His big dream is to have a Red Rider BB gun. That's all he cares about. He tries to convince everyone it's the perfect gift. But nobody else seems to see it that way. Not his parents, definitely. And also not his teacher. Santa Claus ain't buying it either. This is a hilarious journey. Really well made. This is one of those movies I saw as a child in the 1980s that really never left me. It is funny and charming. It has great twists. The acting is really good too. I could go on and on about every scene that made me laugh but that would take too long. It's the only movie you need to see during Christmas and holidays. Okay, this and Miracle on 34th Street. 10 from 10.

Review title: The movie that comes the closest to Showing my own childhood
Review_body: I took my son to see A Christmas Story. Mostly because he insisted. My wife and I weren't so sure, especially after seeing the mean Santa Claus kick the kid down the slide. I'm sure glad I didn't judge the movie by the trailer. My son loved the movie, but I'm sure I loved it more. I can remember seeing Christmas toys in the store windows in Dayton's Department Store (now Target Corporation.) I never pushed my face against the window like Ralphie's brother, but I sure saw a lot of other kids do that. I still can see the frozen snot. And that was just one of the scenes from the movie. They went on and on, and every one so dead right on that I sometimes found myself sniffling. The school could have been my elementary school in south Minneapolis. The neighborhood bully was a neighbor kid. I beat him by not fighting. It absolutely drove him crazy. But I sure cheered Ralphie on when he beat up Skud Farkus. I had a Little Orphan Annie decoder ring, even though Tom Mix and Jack Armstrong usually got my dime. The house where Ralphie lived was exactly like so many of the houses I visited. The attention to detail was marvelous. And the scene where Ralphie puts down the toilet seat and Mom lifted the lid on a pot on the stove was mind-bogglingly funny. By the end of the movie I was heartbroken it was over and I immediately started to send or take my friends. Everyone had the same opinion. It was a classic. That's probably why I've watched it about a hundred times over the years. I expect I'll see it a hundred more before I go.

Review title: The best movie to get you in the mood for the holidays!
Review_body: A Christmas Story is one of my family's favorite movies that we love to watch each holiday season.  Who hasn't been through at least one or two of the experiences Ralphie had that winter.  Whether it be the bullies on the playground or getting in trouble for using some of your fathers more colorful language.  Most kids and adults growing up in suburban America will fall in love with this story.  It is a true Christmas Classic.

This is a wonderful, little movie.  Without any preachiness, it getsacross one message of Christmas, which is that God is in controland good things will happen.  In this case, you will get what youwant even if all of your scheming and plans go completely wrong. Peter Billingsly's insincere face is so dopey that you feel as ifBillingsly, even at that age, must have known it was a putup job. Darren McGavin is compulsively watchable in anything he does. His ability to kvetch must rank with Jimmy Stewart.  As for MelindaDillon, she's perfect because she does everything in this movie indeadly earnest.  She knows that comedy is best when donecompletely straight.  But I think the greatest praise must go to JeanShepherd.  Not only did he get most of his own material into thescreenplay, but his material is good.  This is the only Christmasmovie I know of (and possibly the only movie period) where, whenTNT ran the movie all day, I left the TV on.

Definitely a movie worth watching, then watching again. Nostalgic, funny, heart-warming, appealing to all ages and ADDICTIVE pretty much sum it up. The plot is excellent and the acting is wonderful. Not just "A Christmas Story", this movie is fun to watch any time of the year. Worth checking out!

Review title: Probably, one of my favorite family movies...ever
Review_body: This is definitely one of my favorite family movies regardless of the season.  Sometimes, we watch this movie in July when we want all in to improve our mood.  It is definitely part of our family Christmas movie canon.  In 1984 as I was surfing through some channels (no remote control), I turned to HBO in time to see the beginning of the "flag pole" scene.  I was entranced.  This movie is definitely about american family nostalgia and culture.   Phrases like "You'll shoot your eye out", "Don't give me that look", "You're going to get it" and others just resonated with me.  While the movie is set in the 40s, there were many completely familiar elements even for someone who grew up in 60s.  While my four kids truly enjoy the movie, I think some of the notions appear quaint perhaps dated.  Walking to school, sitting in the living room to listen to a radio program, BB guns, department stores, old-fashioned school bullies and one car families to name a few are becoming increasingly alien to middle class american youth.  The father played by Darren McGavin and the Mother portrayed by Melinda Dillon are perfectly cast.  The narration by Jean Shepherd provided the exactly right accent and pace to the story.  This is a amusing and pleasant tale about a caring family's "adventures" (no kung fu, stunts, or special effects) leading up to Christmas in a time before TV, malls, video games, walkmans, web surfing, DVDs, and cell phones when the pace of family life was just a little bit slower than it is now.

Review title: Its not Christmas unless I see it a few times with the family
Review_body: I am only 30, but I shared this movie with my father because it reminded him of things when he was young, (he was randy's age at the time) all the old nostalgia, the tree's the trains the old furnaces, cars and even with all the bickering families that were together... We watch the marathon every year and its like my father sharing his childhood with us... also its funny as hellMike

How Anybody Could Hate This Movie Is A Mystery. It is an Epic In Every Sense Of The World. It Is Exciting And Lives Up To It's Title. All A Kid Wants Is A Dream Present. But His Parents Are Just Too Uncool. Although It No Doubt Has Changed Over Time From A BB Gun To A Playstation 2 Or An XBOX It Is Still Timeless........My #1 Movie

Review title: I liked it at first, but now.....
Review_body: First, I'll introduce myself as a Shepherd "fathead," an avid admirer of his work. OK. I also saw ACS as among the 17 at its theatrical release--my girlfriend and I were the audience. I enjoyed the film then, but don't care if I ever see it again, especially after seeing again recently THE PHANTOM OF THE OPEN HEARTH, the first film version of Shep's stories. Darren McGavin chews the wallpaper as The Old Man, whereas James Broderick brings out the character spot-on in PHANTOM, doing more with a hard look than McGavin's "NOT A FINGER!!!!" I don't know what the deal was with Melinda Dillon's hairstyle--she looked more like Diane Keaton on a bad day and hardly made me forget Barbara Bolton as Ralph's mom. Shep later said he wanted a more sardonic, anti-nostalgic edge to ACS akin to his stories, complete with out-of-tune music in spots (which PHANTOM used to the right effect)--too bad that got muted. It's worth a look, sure, but it won't make me forget Shep's Christmas Eve reading of the original Red Ryder story ("Duel in the Snow, or Red Ryder Nails the Cleveland Street Kid") on WOR, let alone PHANTOM. Excelsior, you fatheads, and FLICK LIVES!

This movie is simply a classic. I watch it practically every year around Christmas time and it never gets old. The characters are believable, and the one liners are classic. The acting is also good all except for Randy's character. They made him act a little too childish, particularly with that dinner scene in which the mother was trying to get him to eat and she was asking him to show "how the little piggies eat". However, that can easily be overlooked, as this movie features priceless moments from the scene where Flick gets his tongue stuck to the pole to the scene in which the famous "you'll shoot your eye out" chanting takes place.

I finally got the video last Christmas! My brother and I like the story because it reminds us of growing up in Evanston, IL in the 1950's. Same kinds of folks, sames kinds of issues.Plus, I cheered when he beat us Farkus, since I was always bullied when I was a child! The sequel "A Summer Story" is also worth watching!Love the scene in the Chinese restaurant.The ongoing commentary by Jean Shephard himself is worth the movie too!Belongs up there with "It's A Wonderful Life" and "A Charlie Brown Christmas!"Also, who can forget the scene when Flick gets his tongue stuck to the flagpole?If you did not grow up during the baby-boomer's, it is probably hard to identify with this movie, but watch it anyway!

This film rated about a 9 for me due to its many hilarious situations, but then, it seemed as if the writers ran out of ideas (or maybe money) and just dropped everything.  The disappointing ending dropped my rating to a 7. STILL worth seeing, though.

Review title: Fun movie but egregious error not mentioned in "goofs"
Review_body: A fun movie especially for those who were children during the time the movie took place. Sit back, enjoy, laugh, and yes, cry a bit.Perhaps the worst "goof" in the movie not mentioned in the IMDb "goofs" section was the following. Early on in the movie Ralphie is looking into a store window at the Red Ryder BB gun he wants so much. There are several toy trains running and one of these toy trains, a Lionel, is puffing smoke! Sorry guys, toy trains puffing smoke (Lionel and American Flyer)did not make their appearance until the year 1947!!! The movie is circa 1940-possibly earlier-and there just weren't any toy trains puffing smoke during this time frame.There are other errors (goofs) regarding the toy trains but I'll let someone else have a shot at the additional toy train goofs!
A simply terrific Christmas movie for anyone who was ever a child.  I love this movie so much I named my dog Ralphie.

Review title: Beyond a doubt, THE classic Christmas tale!
Review_body: This movie is just a fantastic piece of cinema.  I first saw this movie in the theatre with my family...of the four of us, my father was the only one not rolling on the floor. Ralphie is one of the greatest characters ever scripted.  He IS the movie, although the father and little brother both share some of the more humorous scenes (the furnace, lamp, and meatloaf scenes). This movie IS Christmas at our house...the tree doesn't go up until after the first viewing.  A Christmas Story isn't watched in our house as much as it used to...ONLY because my brother and I have since aged and left the nest.  Although, these past few years have been great, thanks to TNT's 24 hour--12 run marathon. Of which, I am around to watch with my mother, while my dad sounds awfully like the father character, grumbling, "How can ANYONE watch that movie more than once in a row?" Very easily, when it is one as highly entertaining as this one. Great story and great acting!  You CAN'T help but smile when thinking about this movie!

Review title: why do people love this film so much?
Review_body: After seeing it on TNT on Xmas day, all day.  I came to the conclusion that this movie is the most overrated piece of garbage that exists in film history.  Why is this film loved by all? a weak story, unbelievable characters and annoying fantasy scenes.  You want to watch a good Christmas film watch Scrooged or National Lampoon's Xmas vacation.  Avoid this awful film, pure crap.

I find it ignorant that others might find this movie"lame". The wonder of this film is the subtleties it uses to present the full flavor of the era. This is an excellent film to not only enjoy the story - but the many nuances as well.

This movie is not just a Christmas classic, but an American classic. I can watch this movie year round. All of us have a Ralphie in us. There is so many classic scenes I do not want to even name them all if someone did not see the movie yet. The neighborhood bully Furnus terrorizes Ralphie and his friends until Ralphie steps up and gives him the beating of his life. You can also adapt to Ralphie for his quest of a Red Ryder b.b gun. I adapted to this because I wanted a b.b gun also one Chirstmas. I recommend it a must-see and to fully enjoy, watch it three or four times back to back. It's a part of American culture during Christmas time and a movie everyone watches.

Review title: Seriously. What is the hype with this crap?
Review_body: I saw this movie since it was mentioned a lot by everyone as a "classic", funny and heartwarming story about Christmas. So, naturally, I decide to check it out because I try to be open about seeing a movie that I haven't seen before. Man, I should have listened to myself after the first ten minutes of the movie.To give some context, I worked at a day camp for little kids. Some were great, some were not. And those who were not good kids were brats. Huge brats. And whenever I saw Ralphie on screen, I wanted to slap him so hard. Not to mention his parents who are so incoherently bad.Are we supposed to root for Ralphie this whole movie? All he wants is a Red Ryder BB gun and thinks Christmas will be ruined if he doesn't get it. Oh well, at least have a scene where he throws a big tantrum and I'd consider reviewing this movie even better, but no. He gets the gun, shoots his cheek, breaks his glasses and tells a lie. AND HIS MOTHER BELIEVES HIM! AND HE GETS AWAY WITH IT IN THE END! What happened to telling the truth and learning lessons like so many Christmas movies have done? This movie threw that away and it's hard to sympathize with a kid who lies and acts bratty an entire film.The movie was disappointing and wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy. The parents are so dumb, Ralphie is a brat who gets away with everything and the story (yes, it's presented in vignettes, which works in some movies, not this one) is so disjointed, and even the comedy attempts are ridiculously lame. I like Darren McGavin in his other roles but this one makes him so hateable that I feel bad he got this role. I'm sorry but watch other Christmas movies that have a lesson or some nice story behind it and not one about a brat.

Review title: Best Movie I Have Ever Seen About Christmas.
Review_body: This movie comes on TNT every year and every year I watch it. I have read the other users comments and since almost everyone loves this film I would say that the very few of you who dont like it, you are most likely green, you live in Whoville and your name is Mr. Grinch.

Review title: The second best holiday movie of all time!
Review_body: By far, except for "It's A Wonderful Life", the best holiday movie of ALL time.  It is easy for me to say since I live in a small Northwest Indiana town and remember most of the things Jean Shepherd talks about in this movie.  I can even relate to a lot of the things that "Ralphie" goes through in this movie, which is why it makes me feel the way I do about this movie. The funniest thing, it has been almost 20 years since it was made, and still holds the test of time.  I can watch it 20 times every holiday season and never get tired of it.  If you have seen it, you can probably relate.  If you have not seen the movie, all I have to say is - "What are you waiting for?!"

This is the greatest Christmas film ever made. My brother got me to watch it a few years ago and I've loved it ever since. Every Christmas eve we watch it. My favorite part is when Ralphie Says "Oh, fudge."That always makes me laugh. There are many funny moments in this movie. Its not the greatest movie ever made but its the best Christmas movie ever made.

I took my two older boys (and many other families from our home-school group) to watch the movie yesterday at a friend's house, and we all LOVED it! Very family- friendly (don't see any reason for the PG rating?!) It was uplifting and encouraging for all of us, especially friends who have loved ones in the military who have suffered loss of limb (and more!) and still find hope, in part due to motivational films like this one!! There is a strong message of courage, perseverance, and hope throughout!! We also enjoyed the child actors - both were excellent and it is encouraging to see home-schooled children make a "splash" in Hollywood without stooping to bad-words and disrespectful attitudes as the catch for drawing viewers! Although the young boy character, Sawyer, begins the movie with a troubled attitude and dislike for school, we watch his interest and passions evolve throughout the movie, which leads to an attitude improvement toward his Mom, as well. Really, every actor performance was top-notch, in my opinion! We recommend this film for everyone!!

I've watched this a couple of times and have been puzzled by Melinda Dillon's hair. It doesn't look like anything I've ever scene from the 1940's.
I tried looking at other photos of her. She doesn't seem to have that frizzy hair elsewhere.
I wonder why ...

Review title: I BARELY liked this movie before TBS got hold of it.
Review_body: The very first time I saw this movie, I was about seven. I thought it was hilarious, but forgettable.I saw it again a few years later. It was still worth a chuckle, but it's not a movie that holds up to repeat viewings.Around 1999, Turner Broadcasting got hold of this movie, and had a BRILLIANT idea: "Hey, why don't we air this movie twelve times in a row on Christmas?" A more bizarre and nonsensical programming decision has never been made.And yet, here we are, in 2006, and every blasted year, they still run a 24-hour marathon of this one movie.WHY? There are literally HUNDREDS of very good Christmas movies out there. Dozens which are infinitely superior to this gormless masturbation of inane reminiscence. TBS could spend the 24 hours from Christmas Eve to Christmas dinner showing Prancer, The Santa Clause, Miracle on 34th Street, or any of a hundred other movies--and that's not even going into the religious films they could show. And yet, against all logic, they roll out twelve back-to-back iterations of THIS.They have effectively run this movie so far into the ground, its vaunted snow is melting from the heat of the Earth's core.

I never get tired of this movie. I watch it over and over during Christmas time. It's a feel good comedy that never gets old. I love looking at the details of the different scenes and how they dress and talk. I seem to always catch another element every time I watch it. Some of my favorite scenes are when Flick gets his tongue stuck on the flag pole at school, Flick: Ahhhh!! Don't leave me! Come back! Schwartz: Well, what are we going to do? Ralphie: I don't know. The bell rang. Flick: Don't leave me! Come back! Come back! Ahhh. The mother reminds me of my mom too. When she dresses the little brother in his snow pants, I thought of my mother. My mom bundled us up all the way too. We walked to school and she would glop Vaseline on our faces and made us where the ugliest boots. She didn't care about fashion as long as we were warm.

I can watch this movie over and over and never get tired of it. It has become a family tradition that I will watch year after year! The casting was excellent and to have been a low budget film it turned out very well done. There are a few family movies that I like to watch at Christmas and this is at the top of the list. I also enjoyed the 20th anniversary edition so I could see what the actors looked like now. They all still appreciate the welcome they receive from people that have watched this show for years. I like it when actors still care about the movies that made them famous. Thank you to the entire cast for making such a wonderful Christmas movie for us to enjoy.
I have watched it every Christmas and will continue to do so for the rest of my life.

All I could think of is "It's a TERRIBLE film." Christmas Story seems to be a mockery of everything that Christmas should stand for. The film is depressing and lewd. Violence, tis' the season to be shooting, is a theme of the film. It is truly the worst Christmas movie ever. If you want your children to see a more uplifting Christmas film - I would suggest Bad Santa. Or if you don't celebrate Christmas, perhaps Schindler's List. The acting is terrible and the child star is a true Christmas dwarf. Maybe Santa needs a new 'helper' - which is probably what the actor is up to today. :(

Without being overly sentimental, this movie is so sweet and funny. The narrator (Peter Billingsly character as a grown up) makes the movie. His dry observations are priceless. Aside from this year's "Bad Santa" starring Billy Bob Thornton, this is my favorite Christmas movie. I could watch it every year and never tire of it. The cast is wonderful, the script perfect. What else could you want?

I never tire of seeing this movie.  It's so true to life and it's not so sentimental like other Christmas movies.  I love the older Ralphie's observations, they provide so much laughter and insight.Kudos to TNT for running it for 24 hours!  It's funny each time.

Review title: This movie will capture the Christmas spirit in everyone!
Review_body: A Christmas Story is played over and over in our house at Christmas Time. We must watch it twenty-five times each year. To anyone who loves Christmas and remembers each year so fondly, especially as a child, this movie is guaranteed to add to your holiday nostalgia. There is a Ralph Parker in all of us. He represents the spirit of Christmas with the innocence, magic and genuine nature that children have, especially around the holiday season. So watch A Christmas Story this year and it will warm your heart.

Review title: What a great time to have been young
Review_body: Any one who finds fault with this movie is unbelievable. I am sure any one with negative comments never grew up in the late forties or early fifties.I remember the snow suits, the long underwear my mother insisted I wear and indeed the local bully, who eventually got his comeuppance   and there after avoided trouble. And who out there who ever grew up on the Canadian Prairies or Northern states in America have not once stuck there tongue on a metal object in the middle of January. The movie is very believable and takes the viewer back to happier times, I can still smell Lifeboy soap,my Aunts bathroom smelled of it, what a wonderful time to have lived.

My words alone cannot describe how brilliant this film is-for a Christmas movie anyway. I can totally relate to this despite the fact I'm only 15. It's one of my favorite Christmas films of all time! Hell, I even make my family and friends watch it every year around Christmas time to get in the mood (I've turned it into a tradition). Ralphie's the cutest thing I've ever laid eyes on. I empathize every bit of embarrassment he's been through during the movie SPOILER: (ex. When everyone thought he was going to shoot his eye out and they were right, at least they never knew that-heh heh, or when his father caught him blurting the F dash dash dash word). Jean Shepard sure had some Christmas. All in all, the movie's cool, I recommend it to anybody...

I happened by the place where they shot the flat tire scene. It was late one night in Toronto, down by the lake on Cherry Street. I remember wondering what such an old car was doing parked on the side of the road just below the old iron bridge. I never saw any of the characters and I wasn't looking for any. But I remember thinking "this must be a movie shoot" because of the trailers parked off the road. Later when I saw the the car and the bridge in the movie I knew it had to be what I saw that night. Everything in that movie was so "right on" to the time. Even the two bully's in the alley. Very funny. The brother all wrapped up in the snowsuit was priceless. My younger brother had to go through exactly the same thing every morning.

After reading some of the comments that are posted about this movie I am puzzled.  I don't know anybody can't enjoy watching this movie.  Maybe the people that are writing bad reviews are either too cynical or too old to enjoy it. However, with that said, I must say that I think that this movie is perfect for all ages.  There is a character inside us all which we can relate to any one of the characters in this movie.  A Christmas Story is played all the time on TNT during the holiday season.  There is a reason that this is done and a reason that this movie has lasted for about 20 years.  We all know that all holiday get-togethers do not go perfectly and this movie shows the true pleasures of the Christmas season.  If you haven't seen this movie I strongly recommend it.

Wasn't there a dud of a sequel to this called, "In God We Trust," or something like that? It wasn't nearly as good as the original (surprise) but still, I'd like to check it out. A search of that title doesn't turn anything up. I could swear that I saw bits and parts of a sequel. The book from Jean Shephard from which the movie was taken was called "In God We Trust." BTW, I think this is the greatest Christmas flick ever. I saw it in the theaters. I still watch it every year. Every year it still makes me laugh. Now my kids are watching it. They want to see it time and time again. Anyone know the title of the sequel?
35 years after it was made, it's still a joy to watch.

By far my favorite holiday movie. Every time I watch this movie (which is numerous) I return to my youth and that Christmas magic returns. I remember all the smells and sounds of those days just by watching this movie. You will fall in love with the characters and every scene will remind you of something that occurred in your childhood. So many moments in this movie have entered pop lexicon. Fragile, You'll shoot your eye out, triple dog dare, Oh Fudge, are just a few quotes from the movie almost everyone has heard. I suggest bake you some cookies grab you some eggnog and spread out on the couch with the family and sit back and relive your old Christmases through the eyes and ears of an 8 year old boy who wants a BB gun for Christmas.

Review title: . . . Like watching French "Nihilism" and calling it "Joy to the World" !
Review_body: Rather than watch this, I'd catch a French film on the "meaninglessness of life" . . . as it's the most Awful, non-redeeming Christmas Movie I've seen since I was a kid in the 50's ? Struggling with the current seasonal ads for 24 HRS. NON-STOP MARATHONS of TCS, I'm continually baffled that this movie, which focuses mainly on continual disappointment, sad outcomes, and cruelties (of life, kids & store Santas) is joyful or FUN to anybody other than people who love cruel jokes. When I saw it in the theaters, I came joyfully expectant, and left very depressed. If you're looking for a movie with a gentle spirit, inspiration, or any signs of the loving spirit that Christmas means . . . AVOID this if possible !!! I finally read through the IMDb comments and found LOTS of people hated this, also * . . . . while 95% + think it's the greatest movie there is! I'd rather stick myself with a cactus for 2 hrs . . . Oh well, another example for celebrating the variety of people on the planet !! As my Dad always said: Thankfully people DO like a variety of things . . . if they DIDN'T, everything I liked to do, would be so crowded when I got there, that there'd be no room for me !![. . . another happy city guy, with a small town boy inside *]
A timeless classic movie. Perfect for kids and adults alike. Years from now this movie will still be just a popular as it's been for the pst 15+ years.

Review title: A classic? This movie is really, really bad.
Review_body: I don't just mean bad, I mean impressively, surprisingly, stupendously, monumentally, horrendously awful.The people who told me this was a Christmas classic... I wonder when the last time they saw it and paid attention was. This movie sits atop a lofty reputation, which is all that it has in its favor. What is the case for this being a good film?No character is likable. In any scene when the main character is with one of his friends from school, that scene ends with one of them being abandoned by their "friends" to a horrible fate of some kind alone, bullies, frozen tongues, etc.The younger brother lives under the sink and is only able to eat his food when his mom tells him to act like a pig, which he does for a really, really long time (editing, anyone?)in disgusting, glorious detail. Probably that kid grows up to be a serial killer. Mom pulls little Ralphie off a kid whose nose he has just broken, and without waiting to find out what happened, leaves the other kid there lying in the snow, bleeding. Covered in blood. Really, the blood is all over his face.Dad is a more endearing character because he is bumbling and likes to drop the f-bomb around his little kids at home while he leaves the parenting to mom. And now I will anticipate a response in the defense: "but that's how things were." I hope life at the time was better. This movie celebrates mediocrity. The whole goal of it is to connect to Americans because "these things really happened to people." There were bullies! There were teachers, and -GASP- pranks! There were trips to the shopping mall! Creepy elves and Santas! Dorky kids who constantly wore repulsive sweaters! Dogs stole the turkey! STOP THE PRESSES. THERE WERE PINK BUNNY SUITS.Is that really funny? No episode or moment of the movie is really any more than mediocre, the humor is pedestrian at its best moments, and the movie just isn't ever remotely interesting.I didn't know whether to be more disturbed by Ralphie's fantasy about shooting imaginary black people trying to rob his house or by the "amusement" created by Chinese people trying to speak English; perhaps in the end it was the simple fact that all of the terrible stock characters and pedestrian humor and mediocrity and cheesy voice-overs and all the rest of it were structured around a boy's desire to get a gun for Christmas. Which he did.

Review title: Not meant to be "The True Meaning of Christmas"
Review_body: This movie is not intended to bring the "true meaning of Christmas" to the screen. It is meant to make us remember what it was like to be kids at Christmastime during a more innocent era in America.There was a time in this country when a person's word was his bond, when doing the right thing was its own reward, and Political Correctness was where it belonged: in Communist Russia.Some people just don't "get" why A Christmas Story is so popular. I'd imagine these people can't remember believing in Santa Claus, or they can't remember anticipating Christmas morning with a treasure trove of gifts under the tree. These people may have lost their innocence very early in life, but worse, they can't remember it, and only cold cynicism is now in its place. A Christmas Story is meant to help you remember a time in your life when magical things were still real to you, before you were disillusioned by the realities of life.

Review title: A Christmas story 1983 merry Christmas ho ho ho
Review_body: My favorite Christmas film even better than its a wonderful life which I enjoy a lot Warm without being mawkish .IT's based on a book called in god we trust all others pay cash which I didn't really like with the exception of the chapter on which this film is based which was written by jean shepherd who also contributes a witty narration. good performances all round especially peter billingsly as ralphie and the late Darren mcgavin as the father .What really makes this film work though is writer director bob Clark's warm hearted but never over sentimental approach which is the essence of the book and his episodic but still cohesive and humorous script .A few moments in the film may be unsuitable for young children after all bob Clark made porky's as well. But don't let that put you off this is a great treat for all the family. Unfortunately Its not well known this side of the pond unlike America where watching it is as tradiontal as turkey for Christmas dinner a situation which could be rectified by a channel showing it or by it's release on Blu-ray or DVD over here which sad to say is all rather unlikely due to the fact that its more of a interpretation of Christmas more familiar to Americans than us but we this side of the pond should enjoy Its available as either a us DVD or Blu-ray import It's sure to put you in the festive mood but most of all it's very funny .I highly recommend it.
Excellent movie!!! Reminded me of all the classic xmas memories i have. And helped me learn the true meaning of xmas

This is our family's all-time favorite Christmas movie.  It captures the charm and silliness of childhood, and shows the overwhelming desire for that most wished-for gift.  Will Santa bring it?  It is set in the Midwest in the 1930s.  The actors are wonderful, especially Darrin McGavin, Melinda Dillon, and Peter Billingsley as Raphie.  We always laugh aloud throughout the movie, and wouldn't miss it.  Christmas just wouldn't be the same without it.  Not the least bit maudlin or sappy, just good fun.
Delight to watch.  Very true to life.  Great casting and direction.  Never tire of watching it every Christmas.

This movie is definitely a classic at Christmastime.  Everyone in my family insists on seeing it at least once every year, and I know I'm not in the mood for Christmas until I see it.  It's fun to watch, and it never grows old.

Seems that many of the people who hated this movie just didn't get it. Everyone's entitled to his own opinion, but most of the criticism in these reviews seems to miss the point.  This IS just a movie about a little boy who wants a bb gun for Christmas.  The scenes that people keep describing as silly or unkind are that way because the story is told just as Ralphie remembers it years later.  Sure, a department store Santa isn't likely to kick a kid down a slide.  But a kid who's desperate to get his Christmas wish (and who sees everything as an obstacle to his goal) is likely to remember it that way.  The great thing about the movie is the warm way it evokes nostalgic simplicity.  For those who complain about the lack of a plot, anything more complicated would undermine the purpose of the film.Anyway it's a great movie, and those of you who hate it should think back on your own childhood then give it another try.

Review title: This wonderful movie is one of those rare magical moments in the history of cinema.
Review_body: A Christmas Story spellbound me so thoroughly when I saw it in 1983 that I brought my entire family-even my brother-in-law-back to see it.  It is simply priceless, and I can see why Ted Turner and company ran it as a marathon this past Christmas.  We won't see quality and genuine warmth like this often.  With the exception of ET, I don't know when any movie has charmed and captivated its audience so well.  The entire cast and the movie setting are exceptional; Shepherd's narration, like everything else, is flawless. This is what happens when movies are honest.

Review title: The Glow of Electric Sex in the Window
Review_body: This is easily the single movie I've seen more often than any other ("Wonderful Life" is close though). One of the funniest, most nostalgic and most durable films I can think of. Get in the Holiday spirit, dim the lights, get some egg nog or hot chocolate, wrap up under a blanket on the sofa and watch this movie.I triple-dog dare ya!

Review title: A CHRISTMAS TRADITION FOR OUR FAMILY
Review_body: This is THE best X-mas movie of all time. It's hillarious. It's touching. It's an X-mas family tradition. Ralphie's great. And I love "THE OLD MAN", and his sexy lamp he won from a newspaper contest. The funniest scene is where Scwarts "triple dog dares" Flik by sticking his tongue next to a frozen flagpole. And sure enough he does it. But what's funny about is the way Flik screams. He screams as if he were a woman fixing to get murdered by a crazed-psycho with an axe. Anyway, I reccomend this movie to everyone who enjoys movies.

I have been looking at "bad" review postings of this flick on IMDb, and other resources. The bulk of these folks who reviewed it "badly" seem to have a common thread...they hate Christmas movies in general...or they somehow, fail to appreciate "A Christmas Story" in particular; for whatever reason. I reckon I'm no authority on the "quality" of Hollywood movies. But...I know what I like - and have some notion of what the vast majority of viewers are gonna like. I have shown "A Christmas Story" to many folks, from many walks of life, since it was first released. None has ever been less than freakin'wild about it.I guess I can understand that this movie (in some strange way) didn't leave all perfectly satisfied...but I'll never understand why. Different strokes for different folks.We're not talking' Citizen Kane here. For pete's sake...it's just a wonderfully done, wildly funny flick. ...and all but the intractably disgruntled will love it.Rent it, buy it..whatever. Give it a look. ..and...don't shoot your eye out!

Review title: What makes this Christmas classic work is the writing by Jean Shepherd.
Review_body: What makes this Christmas classic work is the writing by Jean Shepherd, who also does the narration. He tried out all the stories on his improvisational radio show on WOR, New York, before working them into the novel on which the film is based. When he was doing the radio show, "Flick Lives!" signs appeared on New York walls and subways. Unlike most Christmas fare, the nostalgia has a satirical edge to it that keeps it from being too sweet. The performance by Melinda Dillon as the mom seems dead on to me, as does Darren McGavin's work as the dad. Classic moments include the tongue stuck to the flagpole and sad fate of the glowing-leg lamp. And of course we all know that if you get a BB gun for Christmas, you will indeed shoot your eye out.

Review title: this is the greatest christmas movie of all time!
Review_body: i mean can you really put together a more timeless and wonderful movie that encompasses everything it is to be a kid, have crazy parents (like we all do), and to capture the meaning of christmas all in the same movie and make you laugh...i think not. this one is a gem of a movie.

Review title: the english appreciate american comedy at its very best....
Review_body: We are an english family, now back in the uk but were on assignment in NY for three years and we came across this wonderful film by chance, and have never seen anything more entertaining for the whole family - it is a real gem of a film and a definite must for all families.  Have at last found it to buy with amazon.uk and are thrilled.

As far as I can tell - jus' 'bout everybuddy has seen this wonderful chunk of Americana.Lotsa folks speculate on the year depicted and I tink I got'n answer.1) The telephone used in the upper hallway is a 1938 Northern Electric No. 2. 2) Red Ryder began being published in Nov 1938... It didn't get onto radio until MUCH later. 3) Little Orphan Annie changed sponsors in 1940 from Ovaltine to Quaker Puffed Wheat Sparkies.Soooooo the time of the story would hafta be Christmas 1938 or (Better) 1939. Then everything would fit...BUT - - - Now.... for the Big Oooops.... The Look Magazine is one of the two December editions of Look from (gasp) 1937!!! 1937 ? ? ? Mama is reading a magazine that is at LEAST a year old? I guess they chose that particular edition because the cover depicts Shirley Temple and Santa Clause.The fix.... use some video pixal magic to change that Look Magazine cover from the 1937 Christmas with Shirley Temple to one the three 1939 Christmastime (from Thanksgiving to Christmas) editions.Other than that...... everything else fits..... the toys (pretty much)... Higbees... the freight depot delivery.Noah 8-?

I didn't grow up in a bubble. I was exposed to television and movies before I can even remember.Being born in the early 1970's, holiday movies were a tradition in my house. Those movies included "Miracle on 34th Street" and "White Christmas". I was later exposed to classics like "A Christmas Carol" with the great Alistair Sim and "It's a Wonderful Life" with the legendary Jimmy Stewart.With that said, I NEVER recall the release of "A Christmas Story" back in 1983. If it had some charm or significance, I don't recall hearing a word about it. The first time I became even AWARE of the existence of the film was when TBS first aired it in 1996 -- FOR 24 CONSECUTIVE HOURS! I sat and tried to watch this movie with an open mind, and it quickly became obvious to me why I'd never heard of this movie until 1996. Apart from Darrin McGavin, there was no redeeming element to this sad, depressing tale that is the poorest representation of a Christmas film that I've ever had the displeasure of viewing.And yet TBS continues its yearly tactic of forcing this overrated, offensive and insulting attempt of a movie on the general public for 24 hours every year (And it appears willing to do so for the REST of the ETERNITY). I've said it before on other movie boards: NO MOVIE deserves this much exposure. Not Casablanca, not Citizen Kane, not the Wizard of Oz. NO MOVIE! I'm sure Jean Shepard is a nice guy, and I guess I SHOULD be a fan of the movie because it's based on HIS experiences as a child growing up in Hammond, Indiana -- just a 10 minute drive from where I grew up.But how does a movie that had very little commercial or critical success become this must-see holiday movie, which has cheapened the classics that have come to define a TRUE holiday movie? It remains a mystery to me.What's even more of a mystery is how film critic Leonard Maltin, whose reviews I generally agree with, would be so duped by recent public appeal of the film (Obviously brought on by TBS's continually yearly tactics) that he would change his rating of the film from 3 1/2 stars to four. And yet he continues to keep The Shawshank Redemption at 2 1/2 stars, despite the fact that public appeal for the movie is GREAT and is the most popular movie on the IMDb! The plot, while based on Shepard's experiences, is TERRIBLY over dramatized (I have a HARD time believing Santa booting children down a slide) and has little charm. It's a painful day-by-day dirge through the depressing life of the Parker family around Christmas time and Ralphie's crusade of convincing EVERYONE that he wants a Red Ryder BB gun as a Christmas present. As far as I'm concerned, NOT getting the gun would have been the ONLY thing to redeem the predictable, contrived plot.Another reason why this movie does not hit home with me is that it lacks a relative message related to Christmas! The essence of Christmas can be defined in the story of redemption (Which movies like A Christmas Carol, Miracle on 34th Street and It's a Wonderful Life beautifully embody). Some might argue receiving a present could be considered a form of redemption, but that would be a pretty SHALLOW example of the word.I guess, in the end, the yearly tactics of TBS have fueled my fire as much as how I just find the movie depressing and offensive. I know many will disagree with my review. But I prefer the aforementioned Christmas Classics, and I'm very happy with that! A Christmas Story, however, remains the most OVERRATED movie EVER!

Review title: So many people tell me this is their favorite Christmas movie!
Review_body:
...but I have to say, after trying to watch it through every few years, that it is (to me) just awful.
For one, if my Christmas memories were of my father using such foul language I would probably not like the Christmas Holiday very much.
In defense of people who like this film, you grew up in a time when life became crude. And life can be be what we make it to be. Art doesn't imitate life anymore.
After being in schools for decades of my professional life I see that life now imitates art.
Life (and our art) can be kind, altruistic, and good. Or we can allow art to cause generations of our young to become coarse and use foul language. It seems each person, and collectively greater society, has already decided.
There are some superb Christmas movies if you can allow them in your home. It Happened On Fifth Avenue, Christmas In Connecticut, The Bishop's Wife... for a few.

I've watched it b/c it was recommended but it's just no good!  It's boring and there are so many better Christmas movies out there.  Why people like this movie so much is way beyond me.  I thought maybe I was the only one but I've talked to others in the same boat.

Review title: Have yourself a warped little Christmas!
Review_body: "A Christmas Story" has been a staple of my holiday viewing for years now. I've always enjoyed this film for a variety of reasons.  One of the biggest is that it provides an antidote of sorts to the saccharine overdose one can suffer from watching too many Xmas movies. Okay, so it isn't "Citizen Kane."  It seems to me, though, that those who negatively critique this film are missing the point and expecting too much. It's FUN.  It's silly. It's not intended to be a serious film.  Films shouldn't always have to be deep statements on the human condition or be accurate and convincing in every detail to be enjoyable.  And it defies imagination how someone could say that "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation" is a great holiday film, and then so openly badmouth this flick."A Christmas Story" views the holiday through what seems to me a typical kid's-eye view.  Ralphie Parker is the kid's Everyman, positively aching for The Big Day to arrive, using every ploy, no matter how ridiculous (Grizzly bears near Pulaski's Candy Store?) to get his coveted BB gun.  I particularly enjoy Ralphie's little daydreams; the outlandishness of a nine-year-old's fantasies is well-depicted here.Though the world presented is a little bit of a caricature, much of the film's view of childhood and Christmas strikes home.  It doesn't present a sugar-coated, romanticized view of childhood, a big plus in my book.

As a 13 year old, one might think I have strong or hateful feelings for an "older" movie because of my younger age demographic. That is certainly not the case! You have probably already seen this film because of its massive popularity and wonder why I'm writing a review about a 37 year old film, the main reason is, well its a great movie as far as screenplay, writing, casting and almost any other thing you can critique this movie on, but it's not all about that sometimes, a movie should be how it makes you feel and when critics stand on a high horse judging every little bit of a film/movie, we can get very caught up. This movie a is a great example of that, the way this film makes me feel is almost indescribable, It kind of makes me feel like I'm nine again, spoiled rotten and very unlucky (at least in my eyes at the time). The way the writers convey Ralphie's (The main character) point of view and thoughts makes me have almost this relatability and connection with the main character really makes this movie for me! If you haven't seen it yet (somehow!) please just go watch it, its a fantastic film that you will most likely love!

Review title: the best christmas movie of all time
Review_body: forget about the movie scrooge forget about the grinch the one movie that showcases what a family does on christmas is a christmas story that is the only movie i will watch at christmas time. the movie is set in 1940 and shows what christmas was like back then this movie pulls me in sometimes i feal like i am in the movie and that i am in the 40's thats how good it is trust me if you havent seen it yet you must check it out and don't werry you don't have to go and rent it just check you cable or sat. around christmas time you will most likley find it heres a tip for you it is on tbs and/or tnt. enjoy it i know you will.

I grew up in those days, and Ralph's story is almost my story right down to Cleveland St and Scut Farkus! Of course, it wasn't named that but the street and the houses were the same.The clothes, right down to the Randy's mittens, were as shown. Mrs. Parker's fur-lined boots were right out of the period; my mother wore those when I was that age. When I see this movie . . . EVERY YEAR! . . it takes me back to those days.I even had a fight just like Ralph against a bully just like Scut . . . and I beat him up - big time! It actually was a turning point in my life. Nobody could bully me from then on! Watch this movie and see if you don't find it one of the best movies of a kid's life in those days. If you were as fortunate as I to grow up in those days, it makes you feel just like Ralph growing up in those magical days.

I Have watched this movie every Christmas eve and Christmas day since it came out in 83(I was 8) and I love it dearly I hope the networks don't stop showing it because it is a true Christmas tradition in my house(and Others) to watch it with my children and hopefully with their children. Many families have grown to love this movie throughout the year and just like mine have a steady tradition of watching "A Christmas Story" every Christmas for as long as it keeps showing. it is enjoyable to see Ralphie and the gang just having their fun and seeing him get what he wants and then does exactly what his mother told him-shooting his eye out. This movie is so funny and enjoyable to watch

Review title: Other movie with Christmas story characters and narrator
Review_body: A Christmas Story is a classic. Everyone knows certain lines and scenes from this movie. My favorite is the leg lamp. We have a house in this town that has a leg lamp in their window during Christmas. Wasn't there another movie with these characters from Disney. I believe they were on a summer vacation but I can't remember the name of the movie. I remember watching it as a little girl. It had the same narrator. I believe it had the same father. They were traveling in a car and stopped at various places. One scene I remember is a antique or flea market. I also think they stopped on the side of the road for lunch. I would really like to find out the name of the other movie. Can anyone help?

Being born in Cleveland Ohio in 1946 I can tell you that 'The Christmas Story' is very accurate to the time line. What I like most of all about the movie is I can relate a lot of the characters because I had some of the same experiences, I even got an air rifle one Christmas. The classrooms in the school are almost exactly what I remember. There was no television yet, only radio, and the schoolyard wasn't fenced in. Even the milk bottles we had were just like the ones in the movie. I believe this movie to accurately portray life in this country in the late 1940's to early 50's. I never get tired of watching this movie.

Review title: Not funny, minutely related to Christmas
Review_body: The language (cursing) by the father is appalling; he acts like a belligerent drunk throughout most of the movie. The mother is a half wit. Just an all around bad movie. Despite the glowing reviews, our entire family (2 adults, 4 children) detested this movie. It was a unanimous decision.Plus, the outline of Cleveland but it is based near Chicago? Also, some lewd material (the lamp) and bloody scenes (fight). We were very disappointed since we looked forward to seeing this movie based on recommendations. My advice, if you are looking for a nice family holiday movie look elsewhere.Terrible movie.

Review title: The Best Family Christmas Movie Ever Made!
Review_body: I was 21 years old when this movie came out and it still reigns as my absolute favorite Christmas film of all time, as well as ranking in my TOP 10 MOVIES EVER MADE. Although I admit that I am biased towards outstandingly created and touching comedy films, this delightful holiday gem is not only on the same humor level as myself and the rest of my family and friends, but I have no doubt that it will continue to entertain generations to come, especially in this politically correct society...this Christmas classic will never grow old! Anyone who does not adore it obviously has no funny-bone in their body nor feel any sense of family holiday spirit whatsoever and I feel genuinely sorry for you! I DOUBLE-DOG DARE YOU TO SHOOT YOUR EYE OUT!

This is NOT my favorite holiday film. It's my favorite film period. I can tune in at any point and I'm just in heaven. No other film I've ever seen does this.  I've seen it a thousand times, and it's never diminished.

Catches the nuances of my time growing up.  Reminds me of a simpler time. All the memories rekindled make this one of my favorites.  I don't know if it was a better time but it was a far simpler time.  I received it this year from my grandchildren and found out they like it also.

I remember watching this movie when i was a kid and feel exactly the same way about it now. the spirit of Christmas kind of dies down in you as you age but great holiday movies like this help you build up your Christmas cheer. I only watch this movie on Christmas eve and Christmas day when the marathon is on TNT its kind of a tradition of mine. For all those who haven't seen this flick really need to check it out especially with Christmas around the corner.A true holiday classic A true American classic A true classic period one of my top 5 favs of all time."you'll shoot your eye kid!"

Review title: I KNOW I saw the Flash Gordon sequence!!!
Review_body: First off, I'm not reviewing the movie. It's a 10 in my book. I love it.The reason I'm doing this is to tell the world that I REMEMBER SEEING THE FLASH GORDON SEQUENCE!!! It was broadcast on TV, I'm not sure of the year, but I do recall seeing Flash and Ming.I recall seeing A Christmas Story on TV years later and NOT seeing the Flash/Ming sequence and wondering where it went.So all this stuff about it not being available, it never being shown, etc. is crap. I saw it. It exists. I'm sure it's copyright issues that prevent if from ever being seen (for now).Does anyone else remember seeing it?

This is probably the movie that I have literally seen the most times in my life. I must have seen it over 100 times and I watch the 24 hour marathon every Christmas. I never get tired of this movie no matter how many times I see it and I don't care if I watch it in Spring or even Summer, it's still one of my all time favorite movies!

This is one of the funniest movies of all time! My family watches it together each Christmas season, and we always laugh our heads off. This movie never gets old no matter how many times we watch it. Some of the classic lines are repeatedly part of our conversations, especially "Frah-gee-lay... must be Italian!" and "You'll shoot your eye out, kid!". This movie successfully takes very real elements of family Christmas celebrations we can all identify with, and makes the most of the humor inherent in each. I hope no one ever tries to do a re-make of this... it's perfect just the way it is. :-)

Reading the good comments on this movie gets a little monotonous, but then I read the "hated it"s and was totally shocked. I can see where someone might not get this movie, but the haters are such humorless prudes! Not to mention that some seem to lack basic comprehension skills (the younger brother does not LIVE under the sink, Ralphie does NOT shoot black people in his fantasies, there is not ONE clearly audible swear word,etc,etc).I saw "It's a Wonderful Life" on a flight recently, and although there were some good touches, the sappiness and especially Jimmy Stewart's overacting really got to me. I kept wishing to see the Saturday Night Live parody version where the townspeople dump Potter out of his chair and beat him up.Then I saw "A Christmas Story" again and loved it just as much as in years past. Admittedly, I don't see it every year and think the TBS marathon is a little much. But this is the only Christmas movie I know of that has recognizably human characters with all their frailties and character flaws but makes you love them nonetheless. Plus it skewers Christmas materialism better than the money-obsessed "Wonderful Life", Santa-cult "Miracle" and goody-goody "Christmas Carol". If you want to see a really gross and unwatchable Christmas movie, try "Bad Santa" for cryin out loud! "A Christmas Story" is pretty low-budget, but that becomes part of its scrappy charm. The loving period design and spot-on performances more than make up for it. If you watch it with an open mind, you won't be disappointed. If you live in a Pollyanna Christmas bubble, you may be!

Review title: Don't watch the movie! Buy the book!
Review_body: Ever since I saw this movie, I wanted to see it again.  It's just that kind of movie.  To prove it watch TNT on Christmas, you'll see it--I did.  I went as far as recording it.  Not to watch it over and over, but to find out who wrote it.  Just listen to the common saying: The book is always better than the movie.  It's based on In God We Trust, All Others Pay Cash and the general works of Jean Shepherd.  He wrote most of the funny chapters for Playboy Magazine, it tells you below the copyright notice.  I have yet to buy a copy to see if he still writes for them.  I just found this ironic because most of the chapters are rated PG and not XXX.  Anyway, don't buy the movie, instead, do yourself a favor and buy the book.  It's just as funny, but more clever.

Review title: Looks to be made by amateurs.
Review_body: This movie has so many things wrong with it that it is hard to find a place to begin.The narration wasn't needed and even if it was one must find a better voice than Jean Shepherd. The voice doesn't work.I never enjoy action that is sped up, i.e., the children running, for the sake of laughs. Some people find that funny but I find it unimaginative.There is a scene where the Ralphie character is in a room with his Mother and both of their bodies are facing to the right but Ralphie is looking over his right shoulder to the left of the camera for two seconds before, presumably, someone off screen indicates to him that he should be facing forward as his Father is coming into the room.Santa and his helpers in the department store are so impatient and ill-mannered that they wouldn't be tolerated in 1940 let alone when the movie was made.I had not one laugh during this film and kept thinking I don't want to see anymore of this and that perhaps it gets better because so many people like this movie.I have to rate this as one of the worst films I've ever seen.Stick with Home Alone as it is entertaining and has some genuine laughs.

If there is any "Christmas spirit" to be had by me, this movie is one thing that contributes to it every year. This is a great and timeless classic, one of those movies I can watch over and over again (I've seen it a few hundred times over the years--since I was four yrs old--thanks to TBS), never getting bored and catching something new every time....whether it be some subtle little fact or something one of the characters said. This heartwarming, satirical comedy is enjoyed by children and adults alike, and sentimental to me, since I've grown up with this movie. Sentimental memories of watching "A Christmas Story" with my brothers is one of the many joyful things I associate with Christmas. The narrator does a hilarious and wonderful delivery in his familiar lines portraying little Ralphie's thoughts and emotions. It's a really brilliant performance to be treasured by all walks of life.

Review title: One of the best movies ever.
Review_body: This is not only one of the best christmas movies ever, it is one of the best movies ever period.  I feel bad for the people that really hate this movie, you must have had an awful childhood if you can't relate to this movie.  I wouldn't change a thing about it.  I really dislike artsy people who write movies off just because they aren't as "deep" and Twin Peaks or something.  If I taught film, I'd play students this movie.

This is an awesome and inspiring movie about pre-pubescent angst. It is about a young boy's hero complex, and his desire to be like all his heroes of the radio age. All he wants for Christmas in his 1940's grade school world is a Red Ryder BB gun, because his heroes are cowboys and all young boys his age want to be like their heroes. He is opposed on all fronts to achieve his desire, but the chain of events he must wallow through are hilarious. He must confront bullies, his parents, his teacher, and his own personal hero -- the department store Santa. Through all this he must comfort his brother and endure his parents tribulations circa 1946. This is a movie for all boys 10-20, bar none.

I saw this movie in the theater when it first came out. It has become a holiday tradition in our house. It has become a favorite among our children as well. A definite must see to help you get in the holiday spirit. A lot of fun.

When this movie first came on TV nearly 20 years ago, I was laughing myself silly. When my 4 children asked why, I put them in the car and drove the to my Mother's house.Once inside, I asked my Mother why I could never get a BB gun when I was a kid. She replied "you would have shot your eye out". When my kids heard that, they understood why I was laughing.My generation was about 10 years after the film, but so much of the film and my generation were the same. The secret decoders, the clothing, the radio programs, and the products throughout the house.Sometimes a movie like this is needed to help us remember where we came from and why we were the way we were. Today's kids don't have that kind of nostalgia, but this film allows them to appreciate ours.

Review title: One of the most complete, dare I say perfect movies ever made.
Review_body: There are powers at work behind the scenes of A Christmas Story.Indeed the Shepherd/Clark Christmas work sets itself apart from other seminal holiday tales because of its contemporary and timeless holiday themes, without the overblown moral drama or the sappy renderings of childhood innocence and nostalgia. The screenplay, based on the work of humorist Jean Shepherd is totally believable in its depiction of mundane middle-class Midwestern life. The father figure for example, (portrayed brilliantly by Darren McGavin) patriarch of the Parker family, is larger than life in young Ralphies eyes, yet bumbling and simple all at the same time. The story purposely dates itself in terms of setting, which only helps to strengthen the nostalgic Americana time-long-past feel of the picture. Make no mistake the phenomenon in the re-playability factor of this film is in part because of the dysfunctional Christmas Story for which many of us can all relate, but there is a real human spirit in the story, a quest for the seemingly unattainable, and a sense that many of the trials of which we endure and cherish as people, are the greatest stories of our lives.

Review title: Why I love and liberals will hate "A Christmas Story"
Review_body: Why I love and liberals will hate "A Christmas Story":Unquestionably, this film contains a pro-gun message. Oh, I know the story line centers around only an air rifle. However, just as some regard marijuana as a gateway to harder drugs, in like manner, many liberals will look upon air guns as a gateway to firearms.Liberals also will view with disapproval the way in which Ralphie solved the neighborhood bully problem. When Scut Farkus saw that his beating by a much smaller boy soon would be widely known, he knew in that moment that his bullying days were over. Maybe Ralphie first should have tried to convince Farkus to attend some anger management classes.
During this time period the school were still segregated.

Sure, the main character is cute and lovable, but that doesn't make the movie a classic. The rest of characters are really caricatures. They are one-dimensional and there is no character development. I saw that someone has turned the house where this movie was shot into a museum about the movie and people lined up to get it. Seriously? SERIOUSLY?

Review_body: Our family watches this movie every year at Christmas time at least once or twice. We know just about every line by heart. Review title: A Christmas Story is a madcap family comedy about a boy's quest to get his dream Christmas gift.
Review_body: In this humorous comedy directed by Bob Clark; Ralphie who is played by Peter Billingsly, his father "Old Man Parker" played by Darren McGavin, his mother "Mother Parker" played by Melinda Dillon, and a host of other wonderfully entertaining characters including Ralphie's brother "Randy" played by Ian Petrella, are pulled into Ralphie's hysterical journey to get the Christmas present of his dreams...A Red Rider BB Gun. From beginning to end this comedy is filled with moments that take you back to your own childhood. This story will pull you in as you take a trip down memory lane with Ralphie, Mother Parker, Old Man Parker, Randy and Ralphie's friends Flick and Schwartz. Along the way there are shootouts, dares, fights and a nontraditional Christmas dinner which all culminate into a great story. Unlike Jingle All the Way where Jamie Langston played by Jake Lloyd is waiting for his father to deliver his dream gift but not actively pursuing it, Ralphie is leaving nothing to chance and will use any means at his disposal to convince everyone around that the only gift worth having this year is a Red Rider BB Gun. One of the other great things about this movie is the Voice Over Narration done by Jean Shepherd who tells the story as an adult Ralphie. Jean does a great job of adding a different dimension to the film by warmly and humorously filling in history, gaps and information. Between his voice over and the special effects that help us to get into the Christmas spirit with cold and snow, this movie is definitely a winner.
I've seen this I swear, thousands of times. Why is it not rated 10/10? Fuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuudge...!
