Review title: A Christmas Story- Hollywood Magic shows secrets of the heart..
Review_body: A Christmas Story is one of Hollywood's wonderful contributions to our Christmas tradition. The genius of the story is that it pokes fun at our very egos, vanities, and material lust, (and that other kind of lust!), while keeping everything within the confines of an All-American household of young Ralphie and his baby brother, during the "peace and love" Christmas season at that.Every day in Ralphie's life is a day dominated by urgency and angst,. Even using the bathroom to use his Little Orphan Anny decoder ring becomes a frantic battle for Ralphie, because of course his baby brother needs to use the bathroom AT THAT VERY INSTANT. (Uhh.. who among us hasn't resented having their secret code-mission territoriality invaded by lesser beings using such commoner excuses??) "Jealous of a plastic lamp?" Ralphie's mom says, after smashing the lamp her husband ("the old man') has idolized as the symbol of his middle-aged virility restored by the magic of Christmas time. Notice carefully: She IS jealous of the sensuous sexuality evoked by the lamp. It is only when her husband says "Yeah, you're jealous that I won a MAJOR AWARD!" that she regains her composure, and is able to dismiss her sabotage of his "major award" as the (his) over-the-hill folly that it really is. The movie keeps jumping back and forth over this line of sexual identity, prowess, and respect afforded to us by society based on those elements. Just watch the interchange between mom and dad when Ralphie is forced to wear Aunt __'s infamous pink rabbit outfit. ("My aunt labored under the mistaken perception that I was eternally four years old, and had been born a girl.") Here it is MOM who is on the ridiculous side of the sexual identity argument ("Oh Ralphie, you look adorable in that!"), and her husband who comes to Ralphie's rescue. Ralphie knows that if any of his friends ever saw him in that outfit, it would make the rest of his schooldom an eternal hell - who among us hasn't been vulnerable to such a social disaster forced on us by forces beyond our control?) Even avoiding the doom of having to wear the insane pink rabbit outfit, Ralphie and his friends have to run the gauntlet of schoolyard bully Farkus and his toady sidekick. When (in a blitz of fighting frenzy) Ralphie turns the table and whoops Farkus, the fight is stopped by his Mom, and later Ralphie's brother hides in the cabinet under the kitchen sink, Randy terrified that "Dad's going to kill Ralphie" (for fighting). Mom placates Randy by offering a glass of music and leaving him in his under-sink cubbyhole, and that evening downplays the fight, winning Ralphie a commutation for his pending sentence (of doom, from his dad, for fighting). Ralphie says, "From that time on, my relationship with my mother changed" - no longer an emasculated little rabbit-girl, Ralphie is now her little warrior man-child. (But note: the emasculating pink-bunny outfit scene actually comes later in the movie.)That is the genius of the movie- Ralphie betrays his friends to be beaten up by Farkus, he exhibits serial cowardly deceit, denial, plotting and scheming - but HE WANTS THAT RED RYDER BB gun, and will FIGHT the forces of evil to get it: including his mom and teacher (both dressed as witches scoffing at his lack of virility in the "cheesy acting" scenes), and of course Ralphie battling "INSENSATE EVIL" in its most pure form, picking off (shooting, killing) Black Bart's insensate gang while his mom and dad cower under the kitchen table. These cheesy scenes are the Cream Topping of the movie (please forgive the mixed gastronomical metaphors!) - Ralphie may be a child, but his "Dead Eye" virility whoops the evil Black Bart's gang, secures Mom's safety, and dad is grateful, even if he has been demoted to cowering under the table.Greed, lust, "unbridled avarice", humiliation, abject terror, the terrifying drunken Santa Claus - these aren't children's themes, these are adult themes! Yet through the magic of Christmas, the magic of childhood, the MAGIC of Hollywood, we can poke fun at these human flaws, and thereby poke fun at ourselves. Chirstmas is about REDEMPTION, about a helpless infant conquering the sins and flaws of this world, and this wonderful movie captures that "TRIPLE DOG DARE" magic . Even as our lives are beset by fears, chaos, uncertainty, and insecurity, yet our innate, innocent (if scheming) childhood goodness triumphs over all. Bravo for Hollywood! Bravo for Christmas! Bravo for childhood!

Review title: A Christmas STORY for all ages!
Review_body: It's just not Christmas till you watch "A Christmas Story" each and every year!For those of us with just a BIT of maturity, our memories will be roused, our hearts touched, our tickle-bones tickled!Young adults and children alike will relate to each "yearning" moment Ralphie does while awaiting Christmas Day and his dream of the PERFECT Christmas gift!We who have survived those who "bully," will ADORE this story!From start to finish, all ages will be able to relate to the Father, Mother,School Teacher, Children, all engrossed in their efforts to create just the PERFECT Christmas for the rest. Treat yourself to one AWESOME, HILARIOUS, yet totally LOVING holiday tale in "A Christmas Story!"

Review title: Don't miss the followup movie "It Runs In The Family".
Review_body: A Christmas Story was probably one of my least favorite Christmas movies for years, and I have a dozen or so favorites that I watch nightly as we approach every Christmas. But by relenting some years to watch it after all my favorites had been seen, I have to admit that it has grown on me to the point that this past post-Thanksgiving season I actually ordered myself a DVD copy for my holiday movie collection. Now I will look forward to watching it each year. *** What totally surprised me however was that there was a follow-up to this movie about Ralphie and the Parkers but which takes place the next summer titled: It Runs In The Family (also titled early on as My Summer Story). Being made 11 years later (1994) all the actors are different but for one heartwarming tie to A Christmas Story; the adult Ralphie narrator (also again writer/producer) remains Jean Shepherd. That plus a homage to the original early in the movie draw you right in. If you liked the original then I'd guess you will want to see this followup, with all its antics, frustrations, and silliness. I liked Charles Grodin and Mary Steenburgen as the parents and although it was a struggle for me initially to warm up to another young actor as Ralphie, he grew on me by the end of the movie. Interesting fact is that Ralphie and his younger brother Randy are played by two of the younger Culkin brothers; Kieran and Christian. I will probably want to add a copy of this to my collection if for nothing more than the tie to the original. Grab some popcorn and watch were the Parker family take you the following summer.

Review title: Strongest and wonderful Christmas movie of its time in my opinion
Review_body: I was going for a long time to see this movie but only now did it and I'm very impressed. Of course, I knew that the film considered legendary and it's brilliantly well but this picture still exceeded my expectations. The film is strong, beautiful, very fun and easy with good storyline. Absolutely all of the actors are superb: Melinda Dillon, Zack Ward, Leslie Carlson and many other... It's just a great carnival rather than a simple movie! And I wanted that toy gun very very much, though I'm 40 ears old now. I would also like to underline that the narration is read by Jean Shepherd, author of this remarkable story. So far I have been unable to find a book to read it but I hope someday it will be possible. Great cinema.

Review title: One of the top 3 Christmas movies of all time
Review_body: This movie will always have a place in my heart. I went to see this movie at the theatre in 1983. I was 9 years old, just like "Ralphie" is supposed to be in the film. After the movie came out onto TV a couple years later, I videotaped it and watched it religiously. I watched it throughout the year, not only at Christmas time. Needless to say, I now have it in DVD format. I have literally grown up with this movie. I recommend this for an "old fashioned - family Christmas". IF you have not seen it yet, what are you waiting for? I was saddened to find out, just as I was writing this, that Darren Mcgavin just passed away. Thankfully, he will always be remembered as the "old man".He will live forever as the "old man".Peter Billingsley can be seen as the head elf in the beginning of the movie "Elf". He was uncredited in the role.The characters will stick with you all through the year. Highly recommended. Other Christmas favorites are any version of "A Christmas Carol" and of course Clark Grizwold in "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation".

Review title: Over-rated and not worth the time
Review_body:
After looking for a Christmas film to watch that we hadn't already seen, this caught our eye. Being so highly rated we thought we were in for a treat, but we were wrong.
Perhaps it's only American's that appreciate this film. Being from the UK, we did not, and found it odd and not what we'd call a classic Christmas film. What the hell was going on with the weird leg lamp?
Maybe avoid if you're not a yank.
